TEXT: The applicant [ Mr PERSON ] is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
He was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as put forward by the applicant , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant was originally from GPE ( FRG ) , where he had first worked as a chartered accountant and later managed an office for a firm of tax consultants . In DATE he set up his own business , specialising in advising and rescuing companies in difficulty . In DATE , before GPE ’s reunification , which came into effect on DATE , he moved to GPE in GPE ( GDR ) with the intention of setting up a tax consultancy there although he had not taken the examination required in the FRG for carrying on the occupation of a tax consultant ( PERSON ) . Also in DATE the applicant acquired NORP citizenship so as to be able to set up his tax consultancy in the GPE .

In a decision taken on DATE ORG ( Finanzministerium ) of the GPE , acting through the Director of ORG ( PERSON Besitz- PERSON ) , granted the appointment ( PERSON ) of tax consultant to the applicant although he had not taken the examination likewise normally required in the GPE for the practice of that profession .
The applicant then set up his tax consultancy , which was quite successful . In DATE he had CARDINAL employees and an DATE turnover of MONEY ( DEM ) .

After reunification , the GPE tax authorities ( GPE für PERSON ) stated in a note ( NORP ) of CARDINAL DATE that the applicant ’s appointment had been lawful and that none of the grounds for revocation referred to in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the ORG ’s Tax Consultants Act DATE ( Steuerberatungsgesetz DATE see Relevant domestic law and practice below ) existed .

In a decision of DATE the tax authorities of ORG ( PERSON ) revoked the appointment pursuant to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) as amended in LAW DATE ( Steuer- beratungsgesetz DATE see Relevant domestic law and practice below ) on the ground that the appointment had been made in breach of the statutory provisions then in force in the GPE . They said that conditions of appointment at the relevant time , DATE namely , the requirement of DATE previous experience as a tax consultant in the GPE – as set out in LAW ( PERSON – see Relevant domestic law and practice below ) had not been satisfied . According to the tax authorities , that Order did not take into account experience gained as a tax consultant in the ORG . The purpose of the Order was , in fact , to facilitate access to the occupation of tax consultant by citizens of the GPE who had the knowledge of the subject required in the GPE , not to allow citizens of the ORG to use it as a roundabout way of gaining appointment without taking the requisite examination .

The applicant appealed against that decision . According to him , his appointment as a tax consultant by ORG of the GPE was permanent and lawful . By virtue of section CARDINALa(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE ( see Relevant domestic law and practice below ) , tax consultants appointed between DATE and DATE had been granted provisional appointments until DATE ; and the subsequent amendment of the Act in DATE was unconstitutional because in section CARDINAL a new ground for revocation had been added , CARDINAL not mentioned in the previous LAW ( see Relevant domestic law and practice below ) . Moreover , he had acted in good faith since he had given all the requisite details to ORG , which in full knowledge of the facts had appointed him as a tax consultant . He had then , he said , made substantial investments in the running of his firm and he could not at the time foresee that his appointment would be revoked following subsequent legislative amendments .

In a judgment of DATE ORG ( ORG ) dismissed the applicant ’s appeal and upheld the decision of the tax authorities on the same grounds . It stated , inter alia , that the provisions of LAW of the GPE ’s Tax Consultants Order were clear , as was apparent from the settled case - law of ORG ( ORG ) in similar cases , and that the provisions excluded any experience gained in the ORG . At the time of the applicant ’s appointment in DATE , there might have been isolated instances of NORP civil servants who , given the general “ end - of - an - era ” state of the regime , had made appointments based on their own interpretations of the relevant statutory provisions , but that had not in any way reflected a general practice .
In a decision of DATE ORG refused to allow an appeal on points of law by the applicant , on the ground that it did not raise a new question of law .

In a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG ( Bundesverfassungsgericht ) , sitting as a bench of CARDINAL judges , refused to stay execution of the decisions of the lower courts . It held that neither the interpretation nor the application of the relevant legislative provisions by ORG , which had relied on settled case - law of ORG , infringed the applicant ’s fundamental rights . That applied both to ORG analysis of the initial conditions to be met for the applicant ’s appointment and to its belief that the applicant must , in view of section CARDINAL ) of LAW , have known why his appointment was illegal .
In a decision of DATE ORG refused to consider the merits of the applicant ’s appeal .
